messages.text: crosspost from <#C67EFTEF3|pkg-usage> <https://medium.com/@alex.birsan/dependency-confusion-4a5d60fec610>

attachments.title: Dependency Confusion: How I Hacked Into Apple, Microsoft and Dozens of Other Companies
attachments.text: The Story of a Novel Supply Chain Attack
attachments.fallback: Medium: Dependency Confusion: How I Hacked Into Apple, Microsoft and Dozens of Other Companies

elements.text: crosspost from

messages.text: The gist of it is that some package managers, when given a package name, by default look in "internal" repos first, then also check the "public" repos and install whichever returns a higher version number. For this attack to be successful in Pkg, the impersonator would have to also know the UUID of the internal package and register a package in General with both the same name and the same UUID.

elements.text: The gist of it is that some package managers, when given a package name, by default look in "internal" repos first, then also check the "public" repos and install whichever returns a higher version number. For this attack to be successful in Pkg, the impersonator would have to also know the UUID of the internal package and register a package in General with both the same name and the same UUID.

messages.text: The MWE is pretty simple, I'll put it into a GitHub repo

messages.text: I think we can fix this

elements.text: I think we can fix this

messages.text: on a Pkg lvl, that is

messages.text: I think the core problem is that some (name,UUID) pairs are only supposed to come from one registry

elements.text: I think the core problem is that some (name,UUID) pairs are only supposed to come from one registry

messages.text: It's actually a feature that you can have the same (name, UUID) pair in multiple registries

elements.text: It's actually a feature that you can have the same (name, UUID) pair in multiple registries

messages.text: That way you can register the same package in multiple registries

elements.text: That way you can register the same package in multiple registries

messages.text: I.e. it was intentional

elements.text: I.e. it was intentional

messages.text: right - we definitely don't want to remove that

elements.text: right - we definitely don't want to remove that

messages.text: but I also think it's possible to say "except these, these should only come from registry X"

elements.text: but I also think it's possible to say "except these, these should only come from registry X"

messages.text: Yeah.... idk how to teach Pkg about that

elements.text: Yeah.... idk how to teach Pkg about that

messages.text: So invenia and/or beacon recently open sourced a few of their packages, and used exactly this feature to make it seamless.

elements.text: So invenia and/or beacon recently open sourced a few of their packages, and used exactly this feature to make it seamless.

messages.text: At JC we are currently planning to register an internal package, and will need this.

elements.text: At JC we are currently planning to register an internal package, and will need this.

messages.text: I don't think there's any plans of removing that

elements.text: I don't think there's any plans of removing that

messages.text: I know, I'm just providing some first hand anecdotes. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I know, I'm just providing some first hand anecdotes.

messages.text: It'd be a great help if some of the folks at JC or Invenia have any ideas how to fix this - requiring everyone with internal packages to basically mirror & vet General is.. non-ideal

elements.text: It'd be a great help if some of the folks at JC or Invenia have any ideas how to fix this - requiring everyone with internal packages to basically mirror & vet General is.. non-ideal

messages.text: but that's the only way this could be guarded against right now, I think

elements.text: but that's the only way this could be guarded against right now, I think

messages.text: The case of open-sourced packages is good, the packages in the two registries are the same. We want to prevent accidents in the case they're different

elements.text: The case of open-sourced packages is good, the packages in the two registries are the same. We want to prevent accidents in the case they're different

messages.text: yeah - unfortunately, UUID is not enough here :thinking_face:

elements.text: yeah - unfortunately, UUID is not enough here

messages.text: We had built an experimental feature a couple of years ago where if there is a name clash between two registries, PKG would prompt the user for input. But that wasn't ideal for many reasons.

elements.text: We had built an experimental feature a couple of years ago where if there is a name clash between two registries, PKG would prompt the user for input. But that wasn't ideal for many reasons.

messages.text: we're already doing better than most by requiring the UUID as well

elements.text: we're already doing better than most by requiring the UUID as well

messages.text: I think that is still there, if you do `add Foo` and there are two different `Foo` (different UUID) you can pick which one. I don't think it has every been used though
